channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudi Explanation of Jamal Khashoggi’s Killing Fails to Squelch Skepticism
item.media:description: The Saudi consul’s residence in Istanbul. Saudi Arabia acknowledged Saturday that the journalist Jamal Khashoggi was killed inside its consulate.
item.description: As doubts swirled about the Saudi account that the dissident journalist was strangled during a fight, an explanation emerged about the presence of a doctor of forensic medicine at the killing.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Mexico’s President-elect Rethinks His Campaign Promises
item.media:description: Mexican President-elect Andrés Manuel López Obrador greets supporters in Tepic, Mexico, last month.
item.description: Faced with the reality of a limited budget and soaring crime, Andrés Manuel López Obrador is scaling back campaign commitments — even before taking office.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Wentworth Defeat Pushes Australia’s Prime Minister Into Minority Government
item.media:description: Dr. Kerryn Phelps, campaigning for legalizing same-sex marriage, in Canberra, last year.
item.description: Voters in a Sydney district chose an independent candidate over contenders from the major parties for the seat former Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull had held.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE TARABAY

item.title: Afghanistan Votes for Parliament Under Shadow of Taliban Violence
item.media:description: Men waited to cast votes on Saturday in Mazar-i-Sharif, Afghanistan, in parliamentary elections that have been delayed for three years.
item.description: The parliamentary vote was delayed for three years by political and security troubles. Both continued on Saturday, with logistical problems and many Taliban attacks.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL, FAHIM ABED and FATIMA FAIZI

item.title: One Killing, Two Accounts: What We Know About Jamal Khashoggi’s Death
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia’s consulate in Istanbul.
item.description: After denying they knew anything about the fate of Mr. Khashoggi, Saudi officials have finally tried to explain what happened. Does their story add up?
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Greece Dispatch: Mount Athos, a Male-Only Holy Retreat, Is Ruffled by Tourists and Russia
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The monks on an isolated peninsula in Greece have followed the same way of life for more than 1,000 years, but an Athens vs. Moscow diplomatic spat and a tourism onslaught are unsettling its habits.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Misery ‘Every Day, Every Hour’ in Syrian Camp. And Now, It’s Grown Critical.
item.media:description: The Rukban camp sprang up between Jordan and Syria.
item.description: The humanitarian situation for some 50,000 Syrians at a camp for the displaced near the Jordanian border has deteriorated, and aid agencies warn it has reached a critical level.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Fact Check: Did Democrats, or George Soros, Fund Migrant Caravan? Despite Republican Claims, No
item.media:description: Migrants from a caravan heading north toward the United States waited on a bridge connecting Guatemala and Mexico on Friday.
item.description: President Trump, echoing the claims of a Republican lawmaker, said that “a lot of money” was given to migrants traveling toward the United States. There is no evidence of that.
item.dc:creator: LINDA QIU

item.title: Sweden Indicts Woman Who Tried to Block Afghan Man’s Deportation on Flight
item.description: Prosecutors said Elin Ersson had violated the Swedish aviation act by remaining standing on takeoff. But she vowed to continue her campaign.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: ‘People’s Vote’ March on Brexit Draws Thousands to Streets of London
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in London on Saturday to call for a new referendum on whether Britain should leave the European Union.
item.description: Demonstrators are demanding a new referendum on Britain’s exit from the European Union, though Prime Minister Theresa May has rejected the idea.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Ceremony for Stalin Victims Is Blocked in Moscow, Group Says
item.media:description: People laying flowers in Lubyanka Square in Moscow in 2009 in a tribute to victims of Soviet repression.
item.description: The rights organization that organizes the event said that city officials had revoked permission, citing “repair and construction work” at the site.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

item.title: In Some Australian Schools, Teachers Can Be Fired for Being Gay
item.media:description: Hugo Walker at his home in Canberra, Australia. He resigned from his teaching position at a private school in Canberra in 2013 after he came out.
item.media:credit: Sean Davey for The New York Times
item.description: Australian politicians are doubling down on a law that allows religious schools, which receive government funding, to discriminate against gay teachers and students.
item.dc:creator: LIVIA ALBECK-RIPKA

item.title: Africa’s Youngest Billionaire Is Freed After Abduction in Tanzania
item.media:description: Mohammed Dewji in 2015.
item.media:credit: Khalfan Said Hassan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Mohammed Dewji, 43, chief executive of METL Group, was snatched a week ago outside a luxury hotel in Tanzania. His company said Saturday that he was safe.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Newsbook: Saudi Journalist Jamal Khashoggi Was Killed While in Exile. These Books Explain the Country He Left.
item.description: Books on Saudi Arabian history and politics shed light on the Saud family’s reign.
item.dc:creator: CONCEPCIÓN DE LEÓN
item.category: The Kingdom: Arabia and the House of Sa'ud (Book)
Kings and Presidents: Saudi Arabia and the United States Since FDR (Book)
Salman's Legacy: The Dilemmas of a New Era in Saudi Arabia (Book)

item.title: The End of a Once Mighty, Still Deadly Industry: the Canada Letter
item.media:description: The Jeffrey Mine in Asbestos, Quebec, in 2011. It closed permanently the following year.
item.description: Until recently, Canada fought efforts to ban asbestos. This week it joined much of the world in doing so. But the deadly legacy remains.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Uproar Over Dissident Rattles Saudi Royal Family
item.media:description: The Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, left, with Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, center, and King Salman. The royal family consists of thousands of descendants of the king who founded the country.
item.media:credit: Bandar Algaloud/Saudi Royal Council, via Getty Images
item.description: Members of the House of Saud are increasingly alarmed by the kingdom’s crown prince but can do little about it.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Facebook Ads From Unknown Backer Take Aim at Brexit Plan
item.media:description: The London offices of Facebook, which announced new disclosure policies for political ads in Britain this week.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The anonymous group’s campaign highlights Facebook’s continuing trouble with political advertising.
item.dc:creator: ADAM SATARIANO

item.title: Evelyn Anthony, Writer of Spy Thrillers, Dies at 92

media:description.p: Evelyn Anthony in 1968 with her daughter, Susan, and their dog. She wrote suspenseful stories of Cold War espionage, a field dominated by men.

item.media:credit: Evening Standard/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.description: Ms. Anthony was one of the few women to explore the espionage genre. “I am basically an entertainer, and I’m very proud of it,” she said.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

item.title: Khashoggi, Female Candidates, Mega Millions: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: As Trump Assails Caravan, a Clash Between Migrants and Mexico Police
item.media:description: In anticipation of the caravan’s arrival at the southern border, the Mexican government deployed hundreds of National Police personnel.
item.description: A tense hour-long standoff near the Guatemala-Mexico border left at least six Mexico police officers wounded.
item.dc:creator: MAYA AVERBUCH and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Saudi Arabia Says Jamal Khashoggi Was Killed in Consulate Fight
item.description: The kingdom’s public prosecutor said Mr. Khashoggi died after an argument and fistfight inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Macedonia Moves Ahead With Name Change, Helping Its NATO Bid
item.media:description: A billboard promoting the name-change referendum in the Macedonian capital, Skopje, this month.
item.description: In a tenuous victory for Prime Minister Zoran Zaev and his Western allies, Parliament voted to proceed with renaming the country the Republic of North Macedonia.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA and ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI

item.title: Julian Assange Says He’s Suing Ecuador for ‘Violating His Fundamental Rights’
item.media:description: Julian Assange on the balcony of Ecuador’s embassy in London last year. He has lived at the embassy since 2012, when he sought asylum to avoid extradition to Sweden.
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder claimed that his longtime hosts at the country’s embassy in London are limiting his contact with the outside world and censoring his speech.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK

item.title: Dozens Watching Fireworks in India Are Mowed Down by Speeding Train
item.media:description: At least 50 people were killed when a train ran into a crowd in Amritsar, India.
item.description: A Hindu religious holiday signifying the victory of good over evil ends in tragedy, as people sitting on railway tracks are killed by a speeding train.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Jamal Khashoggi Is Dead. Here’s What We Know.
item.media:description: Jamal Khashoggi, a dissident Saudi writer and Virginia resident, vanished after visiting the Saudi consulate in Istanbul more than two weeks ago.
item.description: The ghastly saga has strained relations between Turkey and Saudi Arabia, and put the United States at the center of a dispute with a key Arab ally.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: U.S. and South Korea Suspend Military Drills
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis and his South Korean counterpart, Jeong Kyeong-doo, made the decision to delay the exercises, called Vigilant Ace, during a meeting in Singapore.
item.description: The decision was made as part of an effort to give the continuing nuclear negotiations with North Korea an opportunity to work, Pentagon officials said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Three Internet Trolls Convicted of Systematic Defamation Against Journalist in Finland
item.media:description: Jessika Aro, a Finnish journalist, filed a complaint with the police in Helsinki in early 2016 over what she said was a campaign of online persecution.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: Jessika Aro, a Finnish journalist investigating Russian disinformation campaigns, had been called a spy, a drug dealer and unhinged.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Turks Search Far-Flung Sites and Question Workers in Case of Missing Journalist
item.media:description: An aerial view of Belgrad Forest in Istanbul, one of three sites investigators are said to be looking for evidence in the case of Jamal Khashoggi. He was last seen entering the Saudi Consulate on Oct. 2 and is thought to have been assassinated by Saudi agents.
item.description: Turkish officials have claimed that Saudi Arabia orchestrated the assassination in Istanbul of Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist, but have not found his remains.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: 20 Men Convicted of Abusing Young Girls in U.K.
item.description: The men were found guilty in a series of trials this year of more than 120 sex crimes against 15 girls in northern England between 2004 and 2011.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Poland Ordered to Reverse Purge of Supreme Court
item.media:description: A protest against changes to the Polish judiciary outside the Supreme Court in Warsaw last week.
item.description: Europe’s highest court told Poland to reinstate more than two dozen judges ousted by the ruling party, escalating a clash between Warsaw and the European Union.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA and JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: In Khashoggi Disappearance, Turkey’s Slow Drip of Leaks Puts Pressure on Saudis

media:description.p: Journalists gathered outside the Saudi Arabian consulate in Istanbul on Monday as investigators arrived to look into the disappearance of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

item.description: The calculated media strategy has proved remarkably effective for President Erdogan, ensuring that the case remains front page news around the world.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: The Saturday Profile: One of Italy’s Last ‘Story Singers’ Is Briefly Left Speechless
item.media:description: Franco Trincale, 83, in Militello, in southeastern Sicily, for the opening of an exhibit dedicated to his long career as one of the island’s last old-school “cantastorie,” or “story singers.”
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: For more than 60 years, Franco Trincale has sung about worker exploitation, social injustice and more, breaking beyond the Sicilian roots of the cantastorie.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Brexit Will Compromise U.K. Security, Ex-Spy Chief Says
item.media:description: “I don’t believe Russia would have used a nerve agent on the streets of an American or German city,” said John Sawers, who led MI6 from 2009 to 2014.
item.description: John Sawers, who led MI6 from 2009 to 2014, called on voters to reverse the “strategic mistake” in a second referendum, and warned that Russia now views Britain “with contempt.”
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Norway Apologizes, 70 Years Later, to Women Who Had Relationships With WWII Germans
item.media:description: Prime Minister Erna Solberg said of the treatment of the women, “Norwegian authorities violated the fundamental principle that no citizen can be punished without trial or sentenced without law.”
item.description: The women, and their offspring, were punished and mistreated after Norway was liberated following World War II, and some were forced into exile.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Poland Elections a Test for Governing Party’s Populist Message
item.media:description: The two major candidates for Warsaw mayor, Rafal Trzaskowski, left, and Patryk Jaki. For the Law and Justice party, there would be no greater victory than winning the mayorship, and there are few candidates who represent the party’s style more than Mr. Jaki.
item.description: The Law and Justice party swept to power by attracting rural voters with grievance and nostalgia. It hopes to extend its appeal to urban areas in Sunday’s vote.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT and MARC SANTORA

item.title: Afghanistan Delays Election in Province as Key Security Leader Is Buried
item.media:description: Gen. Abdul Raziq, the police chief who was buried in Kandahar on Friday, loomed large in Afghanistan’s national psyche and was revered by the security forces.
item.description: Voting in the national parliamentary elections will be postponed for a week in Kandahar Province, where the police chief, Gen. Abdul Raziq, was gunned down on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: At War: Afghan War Casualty Report: Oct. 12-18
item.media:description: People gather for the funeral of a prominent Afghan politician who was killed in a bomb attack in Helmand.
item.description: 140 security force members were killed during the past week as fighting spread to 14 provinces.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED

item.title: Sagrada Familia, a Barcelona Masterpiece, and Scofflaw?
item.media:description: Construction of the Sagrada Familia started in 1882, but it was only about a quarter completed when its architect, Antoni Gaudí, died in 1926.
item.media:credit: Daniel Rodrigues for The New York Times
item.description: The basilica will pay $41 million to settle a dispute over taxes, infrastructure and a building permit the city says the church should have gotten a century ago.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Japan Caved to Trump on Trade Talks. Now the Real Haggling Begins.
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan acquiesced to President Trump in New York last month, agreeing to bilateral trade talks with the United States instead of discussions involving multiple countries.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Tokyo could offer minor concessions to give Washington a face-saving deal, but already the U.S. is signaling a tough stance on autos and agriculture.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Anjem Choudary, Radical Islamist Preacher, Is Freed in Britain, but Under Strict Controls
item.media:description: Anjem Choudary leaving the London Central Mosque after speaking at a rally in 2015.
item.description: Mr. Choudary, convicted of inciting support for ISIS, was freed on Friday under rules that will bar him from leaving London, using the internet without permission and attending certain mosques.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Australia Dispatch: Preserving a Culture by Protecting the Environment
item.media:description: Gatha Pura Mununggurr, 28, a member of the Dhimurru Rangers, hunting for dinner after a day of cleaning a beach of debris.
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.description: The Dhimurru Rangers are one of more than 100 Indigenous groups spread across Australia who are removing thousands of pounds of plastic garbage from the beaches.
item.dc:creator: Photographs and Text by DAVID MAURICE SMITH

item.title: Mike Pompeo Warns Panama Against Doing Business With China
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, left, with Panama’s president and vice president, Juan Carlos Varela and Isabel Saint Malo, in Panama City on Thursday. Mr. Pompeo warned against “predatory economic activity” by China.
item.description: China is the second-biggest user of the Panama Canal, and Washington worries about Panama becoming a beachhead for Chinese influence.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Nikki Haley Pokes Fun at Trump, and Herself, at Al Smith Dinner
item.description: The United Nations ambassador, who has announced she will resign at year’s end, tried her hand at humor as guest speaker.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Voices From the Caravan: Why These Honduran Migrants Are Heading North
item.media:description: Honduran migrants stop to rest in Guatemala City.
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.description: Thousands of Honduran migrants are making their way toward the U.S. border. We asked several why they had chosen to make the journey north and what they had left behind.
item.dc:creator: DANIELE VOLPE and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Khashoggi, Afghanistan, Abuse: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: What Is the Migrant Caravan and Why Does Trump Care?
item.media:description: The migrant caravan was formed late last week in San Pedro Sula, a city in northern Honduras known for high levels of violence.
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.description: As many as 4,000 people are walking together north from Central America, fleeing violence or poverty. The president wants them to stop.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: The Saudi General Taking the Fall in the Khashoggi Case
item.description: A Saudi official has said Maj. Gen. Ahmed al-Assiri, a high-ranking adviser to the crown prince, organized the operation that killed the journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
